A Smithsonian magazine special report
Historians Thought This Rare Renaissance Portrait by One of the First Famous Female Artists Was Lost to History—Until It Surfaced in North Carolina
Sofonisba Anguissola’s 16th-century painting of a clergyman was known only through a black-and-white photo. However, the original had been hiding in a private collection in North Carolina since 1977
A long-lost painting by Sofonisba Anguissola—one of the few famous women artists of the Renaissance—has resurfaced in New York City. Her Portrait of a Canon Regular, painted in 1552, was recently displayed at the Winter Show, marking its first time on public view.
Portrait of a Canon Regular depicts an unidentified clergy member mid-lecture. His right hand touches the pages of a Bible, open to the Gospel of John. An eagle, a symbol of St. John, holds the book aloft in its talons, “hovering somewhat menacingly in the dark,” per a statement from Robert Simon Fine Art, the gallery that presented the piece.
Anguissola “worked with deeper study and greater grace than any woman of our times at problems of design,” wrote the 16th-century Renaissance artist and biographer Giorgio Vasari. “For not only has she learned to draw, paint and copy from nature, and reproduce most skillfully works by other artists, but she has on her own painted some most rare and beautiful paintings.”
Portrait of a Canon Regular made its debut at the Winter Show, an art fair held at the Park Avenue Armory on the Upper East Side. The painting was presented with a price tag of $450,000, reports Artnet’s Eileen Kinsella. According to the gallery, the canvas is one of fewer than 20 signed paintings by Anguissola that survive today.
Until recently, Portrait of a Canon Regular was thought to be lost. The Frick Art Reference Library had a black-and-white photo of it dated to the 1920s, but the trail stopped there, reports Artnet. Then, in 2024, art historian Michael Cole, author of the book Sofonisba’s Lesson, gave a lecture about Anguissola at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. The talk was posted on YouTube.
Fortunately, the owners of the original painting, based in Durham, North Carolina, watched the lecture. They had inherited the piece from their relatives, who had purchased it at a North Carolina auction in 1977.
“I was initially approached to value the painting and to consult on its conservation, provenance and proper framing,” art dealer Robert Simon tells Artnet. “In the end, the owners decided to sell the painting, and I am acting as their agent in bringing it to a wider audience.”
Anguissola was born in Cremona, Italy, around 1532. Encouraged by her father, she began artistic training as a teenager and quickly showed promise. Her early work was even praised by Michelangelo, who corresponded with her father. Anguissola painted Portrait of a Canon Regular when she was around 20; the portrait is her earliest signed and dated piece.
Fun fact: Sofonisba Anguissola’s early work
Michelangelo complimented Anguissola’s portrayal of a young child in Boy Bitten by a Crayfish (circa 1554), according to the National Museum of Women in the Arts.
By the late 1550s, Anguissola’s artistic reputation had extended beyond Italy. In 1559, the king of Spain, Philip II, asked her to be a lady-in-waiting to his third wife, Elisabeth of Valois. Anguissola lived in the Spanish court for 14 years, painting portraits of the royal family, teaching the queen to draw and caring for children. After marrying the brother of the Viceroy of Sicily, she moved to the Italian island, where she would live until her death in 1625.
“Sofonisba wasn’t just anybody,” Salvatore Patane, a Sicilian priest, told the London Times’ Julia Buckley in November 2025. Anguissola lived in Patane’s town, Paterno, which recently held a celebration of the artist. “She was a woman who managed to leave home and go to the most important court of the time,” he added.
Anguissola’s position in the Spanish court provided security and status, but its strict artistic standards tamped down her creativity, Simon tells the Art Newspaper’s Carlie Porterfield. “In Spain, every portrait had to look kind of alike, so she lost a lot of the inventiveness,” he says.
As such, Anguissola’s earlier work from Italy—“her brilliant portraits of the 1550s”—are highly valued, Simon tells Artnet. Per the Times, Vasari wrote that Anguissola’s portraits were “done so well that they appear to breathe.”
Anguissola produced many detailed portraits of herself, royals, nobles and several clergymen. On the desk before the subject of Portrait of a Canon Regular is a Turkish carpet, “a preferred device of the artist that is found in several variations in her works,” Simon tells Artnet. The portrait was recently conserved, revealing her full signature: “Sophonisba Anguissola Virgo,” followed by the date 1552.
Though Anguissola gained important recognition during her life, her artistic reputation faded over the centuries. Some of her works were misattributed. For a long time, Anguissola’s Juana of Austria and a Young Girl (1561-62) was credited to the Italian master Titian.
In recent decades, however, many exhibitions have been dedicated to Anguissola’s work. Per the National Gallery of Art, “She is increasingly recognized as one of the major figures of the later Italian Renaissance.”
“You can’t find a mediocre woman artist [from this time], as they would not have had a career, right?” Simon tells the Art Newspaper. “They had to be really good.”

From Giant Art to Amazing Specimens, See These 20 New and Revitalized Smithsonian Shows in 2026
The Institution’s museums are commemorating America’s 250th birthday, showcasing the art of noise and displaying the best of portraiture
As the world’s largest museum group, the Smithsonian comprises 21 museums and the National Zoo. Each year, its museums unveil exhibitions that aim to educate, entertain and surprise visitors. This year brings an array of new exhibitions to the Smithsonian’s museums, exploring things like the groundbreaking designs that have influenced music history and marking the nation’s 250th anniversary. In addition, museumgoers can expect the completion of large, multiyear renovation projects at the National Air and Space Museum and the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden.
Here are 20 informative, fascinating and fun shows to look forward to in the coming year. (Dates subject to change.)
Quick facts: America 250
- As the observation of America’s 250th birthday commences, the Smithsonian is presenting a number of exhibitions and programs with the aim of “not only celebrating this historic event but also making it a time of reflection.”
- This year, the Smithsonian Castle will reopen from Memorial Day weekend to Labor Day with the “American Aspirations” exhibition, the National Museum of American History will highlight 250 collection objects, the National Museum of African American History and Culture will celebrate its 10th anniversary with a block party and the National Air and Space Museum will complete its renovation for its 50th anniversary.
“Big Things for Big Rooms” at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden
This exhibition, which opened in the closing weeks of 2025, combines rarely seen large-scale works from trailblazing artists such as Dan Flavin, Sam Gilliam, Robert Irwin, Lygia Pape and Richard Long, alongside contemporary artists whose work has expanded on the ideas of the earlier creators. Largely drawn from the Hirshhorn collection, five pieces are on view at the museum for the first time. (Through July 4, 2027)
“At the Vanguard: Making and Saving History at Historically Black Colleges and Universities” at the National Museum of African American History and Culture
The display includes more than 100 objects collected from five historically Black colleges and universities—Clark Atlanta University, Florida A&M University, Jackson State University, Texas Southern University and Tuskegee University—that represent the history of the schools and tell stories of the innovations and discoveries that have enriched life for all Americans. (Through July 19, 2026)
“Here: Pride and Belonging in African Art” at the National Museum of African Art
An exploration of LGBTQ+ artists from Africa and its diasporas, this exhibition features nearly 60 artworks, including pieces by artists Zanele Muholi, Toyin Ojih Odutola, Rotimi Fani-Kayode, Leilah Babirye and Jim Chuchu. The show celebrates intimacy, faith, family and joy as it demonstrates how these artists are part of a larger story of African art history. (Through August 23, 2026)
“The Outwin 2025: American Portraiture Today” at the National Portrait Gallery
The seventh triennial Outwin Boochever Portrait Competition was bumped from 2025 to 2026 due to the government the shutdown. Its 34 portraits by 35 artists were drawn from 12 states, Puerto Rico and Washington, D.C. Its first-prize $25,000 winner, Kameron Neal, will also be commissioned to portray a notable living American for the National Portrait Gallery collection. (Through August 30, 2026)
“Art of Noise” at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum
The art that accompanies and enhances music will be celebrated in an exhibition that includes concert posters, album cover art, photographs and the designs of digital music players and radios. Drawn from the collections of Cooper Hewitt and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, which organized the exhibition, “Art of Noise” will include sound installations by artist Devon Turnbull. (February 13, 2026, through August 16, 2026)
“Nick Cave: Mammoth” at the Smithsonian American Art Museum
Renowned contemporary artist Nick Cave, known for his Soundsuits series, reveals a new body of work. “Mammoth” is an immersive exhibition showcasing the crafted hides and bones of woolly mammoths, as well as a video projection that will bring the extinct beasts to life and a beaded curtain depicting the Missouri farm where Cave grew up. As with much of his work, Cave, 66, will explore fraught American history with observations about land and race. (February 13, 2026, through January 3, 2027)
“Into the Waters With Senju and Bingyi: Two Contemporary Paintings” at the National Museum of Asian Art
Two contemporary artists, working with grand scales, are united in their inspiration and depictions of water: Japanese painter Hiroshi Senju’s representations of waterfalls on folding screens and Chinese painter Bingyi’s three hanging scrolls of smashed ink depicting the effects of the sea breeze. (April 2, 2026, through September 27, 2026)
“Of the Hills: Pahari Paintings From India’s Himalayan Kingdoms” at the National Museum of Asian Art
This display of paintings made for Hindu kings between the 1620s and 1830s includes works which have never been publicly shown and showcases new revelations about the artists’ communities at the time. (April 18, 2026, through July 26, 2026)
“In Pursuit of Life, Liberty & Happiness” at the National Museum of American History
Already the home of the original Star-Spangled Banner, the museum will mark the nation’s 250th anniversary with an exhibition spanning three floors and 300,000 square feet. From its more than 1.7 million artifacts, the museum presents 250 objects to tell the country’s story, including the desk Thomas Jefferson used to draft the Declaration of Independence and the gunboat Philadelphia, the oldest surviving American Revolution fighting ship. (Opens May 14, 2026)
“We Make History” at the Anacostia Community Museum
The Anacostia Community Museum commemorates America’s 250th by spotlighting the importance of local history keeping and civic engagement: preserving records, creating collections and helping to craft the country’s historical narrative. (Opens May 30, 2026)
“Bison: Standing Strong” at the National Museum of Natural History
The rise, fall and return of the great American mammal is traced from ancient times to the present. The Smithsonian has a long association with the bison, as a few of them were kept in a pen outside the old Smithsonian Castle in the late 19th century. Now, the National Museum of Natural History aims to educate visitors about the animal’s past and the restoration of bison herds to the American prairie. (Opens May 2026)
“¡Puro Ritmo! The Musical Journey of Salsa” at the National Museum of American History
Presented by the National Museum of the American Latino, this exhibition will share the rhythm, movement and heritage of salsa music in the National Museum of American History’s Molina Family Latino Gallery. The multimedia approach tells the story of salsa, noting its global impact and place alongside other music traditions. (Opens spring 2026)
“From These Lands: Sharing Our Natural and Cultural Heritage” at the National Museum of Natural History
Some of the most awe-inspiring specimens and cultural items drawn from all 50 states—as well as Washington, D.C. and five inhabited territories—will be on display to reflect the kaleidoscopic diversity of America. (Opens June 2026)
“RTX Living in the Space Age Hall” at the National Air and Space Museum
Visitors will learn about the past, present and future of space technologies, including Earth observation systems, rockets and missiles, and how they have changed our lives. The museum presents artifacts such as a full-scale mockup of the Hubble Space Telescope and the Skylab Orbital Workshop backup. (Opens July 1, 2026)
“Jay I. Kislak World War II in the Air” at the National Air and Space Museum
This gallery explores military aviation during World War II and how aircraft transformed the nature and experience of warfare. Some never-before-displayed artifacts include a rare surviving Soviet Ilyushin Il-2 airplane. (Opens July 1, 2026)
“The Ascent of Rauschenberg: Reinventing the Art of Flight” at the National Air and Space Museum
The work of artist Robert Rauschenberg is celebrated in this yearlong exhibition of 30 works. Flight was a consistent theme in Rauschenberg’s art, as he depicted birds, insects and spacecraft. (July 1, 2026, through summer 2027)
“Much Here Is Beautiful: Photography Surveys of the U.S. Bicentennial” at the Smithsonian American Art Museum
Just before the 200th birthday of the country in 1976, the National Endowment for the Arts created a multiyear program to help chronicle every corner of the States. The result, thousands of images from more than 200 photographers, allows a look at the nation a half-century ago. The museum presents a selection of images from the photography surveys just before and after the bicentennial, along with some from the 19th century. (September 18, 2026, through April 18, 2027)
Hirshhorn Sculpture Garden Reopening
The renovation of the sculpture garden, which began in 2023, was designed by Hiroshi Sugimoto, who previously redesigned the Hirshhorn Museum lobby. The sculpture garden, which is a little more than an acre, will feature selections from the museum’s growing collection of artwork, alongside favorite works such as Yoko Ono’s Wish Tree for Washington, D.C. (Opens fall 2026)
“Handwork: Contemporary Craft” at the Renwick Gallery
In this exhibition, more than 100 objects shed light on the world of handmade crafts, including new acquisitions from artists Roberto Benavidez, Angela Ellsworth, Bill Harris, Aya Oki, Ato Ribeiro and Jan Yager. (Opens November 13, 2026)
“Photographic Memory: Fifty Years of Photography at the National Portrait Gallery”
The museum celebrates a half-century of its extensive photography collection by presenting more than 100 works, highlighting the significance of the medium in capturing the portraits of many who never posed for paintings or sculptures. The exhibition will include a recently acquired 1846 daguerreotype of Dolley Madison and the famous cracked-plate portrait of Abraham Lincoln, along with photos of Lee Miller, Ruth Asawa, James Brown and Serena Williams, among others. (Opens November 14, 2026)

Archaeologists Unearth a Reusable School Slate Still Covered in the Scribbles of Victorian Children
The slate was found alongside other evidence of young students’ schoolwork and play at the site of a new development in London
Archaeologists have discovered a trove of rare artifacts used by children at the site of a new development in London.
While preparing for construction, researchers unearthed several marbles, a pencil and a fragment of a reusable slate tablet with letters scratched into the surface.
“We don’t often find archaeological objects we can directly link to children, but here we were delighted to find evidence for both schoolwork and play,” according to a January 12 update from the Museum of London Archaeology (MOLA), which is leading the dig.
The marbles—some of which are still covered in colorful decorations—are what’s known as “ceramic alleys,” or small, smooth spheres designed to look like they were made from alabaster. They were discovered in a covered, brick-lined drain, which suggests they may have been lost during “a breaktime game,” per MOLA.
The tablet, meanwhile, was probably a useful tool for taking notes. “Children would have used chalk or slate pencils to copy down from the blackboard or practice their handwriting and rubbed them clean for the next lesson,” according to MOLA.
Archaeologists don’t know exactly how old the children’s artifacts are, but they hope to find out. They’re also trying to make out the scribbles on the tablet, per Fox News Digital’s Andrea Margolis.
“We’re currently exploring this as part of our post-excavation work on the site, so we hope to be able to share more soon,” Alex Blanks, a MOLA senior archaeologist, tells the outlet.
The dig site, located in east London, will soon be home to SEGRO Park Wapping, a new industrial and logistics hub. However, hundreds of years ago, it was home to a free school for impoverished boys, as well as residences for poor elderly people.
The researchers say these structures were established in 1536 by Nicholas Gibson, an elected sheriff of London, and later supported by his widow, Avice Knyvet, who asked the Worshipful Company of Coopers to look after them.
The group made and repaired wooden casks and barrels in London starting in the 1400s, but it also supported charities and education initiatives. Many residents of the community had direct links to the profession—such as a father, husband or son who worked as a cooper.
According to a 1598 survey of London, the structures were “for the instruction of 60 poor men’s children, a schoolmaster and usher with fifty pounds ... also ... alms houses for 14 poor aged persons, each of them to receive quarterly six shillings and eight pence the piece for ever,” per MOLA. The homes’ first inhabitants were primarily older, widowed women, but by 1720, men were also living at the site, records show. Each resident had a room, a cellar and a small garden.
In addition to the children’s items, archaeologists also unearthed the remains of a chapel, row houses and other buildings, as well as brick-lined cesspits and wells filled with items. The dig revealed a “little microcosm of a whole community,” Blanks tells BBC News’ Tim Stokes.
The excavation turned up artifacts ranging from the Roman occupation of London (from the first to the fifth centuries) to the Victorian period (from 1837 to 1901), including pieces of glassware, pottery and clay pipes.
Did you know? Château Margaux
The prestigious French vineyard Château Margaux was a favorite of famous figures like Thomas Jefferson, America’s third president, and Robert Walpole, Britain’s first prime minister.
Archaeologists also recovered the seal from a bottle of wine produced by a high-end French winery called Château Margaux. That was a bit of a surprise, because the area—which was once known as Sailor Town—was long considered “overcrowded and dangerous,” Blanks says in a statement.
“But finds like this are revealing a more complex social history than often biased contemporary sources would have you believe,” he adds. “In reality, it was a very diverse area—just like the East End is today. Archaeological evidence ... suggests people from a wide range of social standings may have been living in the area and getting to enjoy some of the same luxuries as the richest in society.”

An Asian Elephant Was Born at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo for the First Time in Almost 25 Years. Now, You Can Help Pick Her Name
The calf was born to 12-year-old Nhi Linh, a first-time mother, and 44-year-old Spike. The pair bred as part of a program working to conserve the endangered species
In the wee hours of February 2, the world welcomed a new Asian elephant. She is the first calf of this species born at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute (NZCBI) since late 2001.
Soon after the baby’s birth at 1:15 A.M. Eastern Standard Time, staff performed a neonatal exam and deemed her “healthy, alert and bright-eyed,” according to a statement. At the time, she weighed 308 pounds and measured 38.5 inches tall.
Assisting with the exam is “really hard to describe, because it’s something I’ve wanted to do for years,” Robbie Clark, elephant manager and acting curator of Elephant Trails at NZCBI, tells Smithsonian magazine. “I’m honestly still absorbing what happened. I haven’t slept since she was born.”
This bundle of joy was born to first-time mother Nhi Linh, who is 12 years old, after a 21-month-long pregnancy. She bred with 44-year-old Spike in April 2024. The calf will not be viewable by Zoo visitors for up to a month while she bonds with her mom, the rest of the herd and animal care staff.
The baby doesn’t have a name yet, and NZCBI wants the public to help choose it. From today through February 13 at 12 P.M. Eastern Standard Time, fans who donate at least $5 to Asian elephant care and conservation through the Zoo’s website can choose from four options of Vietnamese origin, and $1 represents one vote:
Linh Mai [LIN-my]: Linh means “spirit” or “soul”; Mai refers to the apricot blossom, a flower associated with Tết (Lunar New Year), which begins February 17.
Thảo Nhi [TOW-nee]: Thảo means “gentle” or “kind” and is associated with nature; Nhi means “small,” “little one” or “beloved.”
Tú Anh [TOO-ahng]: Tú means “talented” or “gifted”; Anh means “bright” and “intelligent.”
Tuyết [TWET]: traditionally means “snow,” referencing the calf’s winter birth.
NZCBI will announce the calf’s name on its website in late February.
Parents Nhi Linh and Spike bred as part of a Species Survival Plan program, managed by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums, that aims to create a stable, genetically diverse population of Asian elephants. Fewer than 52,000 of these animals are estimated to remain in their homeland of South and Southeast Asia. “Asian elephants are very endangered. Actually, they’re ten times more endangered than African elephants,” Peter Leimgruber, NZCBI’s director of conservation and science, tells Smithsonian magazine.
The species’ population continues to dwindle largely because of human-induced habitat loss from activities such as agriculture, mining and urbanization. But insights gained at the Zoo can help conservationists working with wild Asian elephants.
“Many of the things we learn here—technologies, the science—we can directly transfer to these places [where the animals live],” Leimgruber says. For example, staff could show people how to monitor the elephants’ reproductive cycles via hormones and determine which individuals should be bred to maintain genetic diversity, he notes.
Genetics, health and temperament helped experts determine that Spike and Nhi Linh should breed. Nhi Linh is described as having a “feisty and rambunctious” personality, per the statement. She arrived in the fall of 2022, along with her mother, 22-year-old Trong Nhi, as a gift from the Rotterdam Zoo in the Netherlands. Meanwhile, Spike seems to have a “relaxed and easygoing” personality, according to keepers, and came to NZCBI in the spring of 2018 on loan from Zoo Miami.
Fun fact: The last Asian elephant born at NZCBI
Male elephant Kandula was born at the Zoo on November 25, 2001. He left NZCBI when he was almost 14 years old and now lives at the Oklahoma City Zoo. His mother, Shanthi, stayed in Washington, D.C., and died at the estimated age of 45 in 2020.
Zoo staff have been carefully monitoring Nhi Linh over the past few months. In late January, blood draws revealed that her levels of the hormone progesterone had plummeted—a signal that she would soon give birth. On January 25, the care team began an around-the-clock watch to keep an eye out for behavioral signs of labor, such as tail flapping and abdominal muscle contractions.
A big indicator is something called the bulge. “That’s when the calf has moved with contractions to a point where you can see externally it’s pushing and getting ready to move,” Clark says. That happened soon after 12:30 A.M. Eastern Standard Time on February 2, he adds, “and within a half hour, her water had broken and the calf was on the ground.”
The calf has not yet met her mother. The two can smell and hear one another, but a barrier sits between them. Staff are watching behavioral cues to assess when Nhi Linh might be ready to meet her baby. An encouraging sign that they’re currently seeing is Nhi Linh being the only elephant to respond to the calf’s calls, Clark says.
“Once we can secure that bond—and typically, the magic point is nursing—then we’ll give them a little time to learn how to orientate around each other,” he says.
